answer:

Services

terminologies.meaning: Use by the program to interact with the user.
A componenet which runs in the background without direct interaction with the user. As the service has no user interface, it is not bound to the lifecycle of an activity.

Can provide data to other applications or components. A provider must be decared in the manifest file for hte application. Consumers access the dat provided via URI's. A provider allows applications to access data.
Android componenet which allows you to register for system or application events. All registered receivers for an event are notified by the Android runtime once this event happens.

question: What are Activity Lifecycles, when are they triggered?
answer: onCreate(), onStart(), onResume(), onPause(), onStop(), onDestroy(), onRestart()

termiologies.meaning:
When the view is first created.
Where we create views, get data from bundles, etc.
When the activity is becoming visible to the user. Followed by onResume() if the activity comes to the foreground, or onStop() if it becomes hidden.
When the activity will start interacting with the user. At this poitn your activity is at the top of the activity stack, with user input going to it.
When an activity is going into the background, but has not (yet) been killed.
When app is no longer visible to the user.
Called after your activity has been stopped, prior to it being started again.

associated_questions.related_question: What is the difference between onCreate() and onStart()?
associated_questions.related_answer: onCreate() is called once during the Activity lifecycle, onStart() is called whenever the Activity becomes visible to the user.
